awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ENTeR: Enabling NeTwork Research and the Evolution of a Next Generation Midscale Research Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past decade the Global Environment for Networking Innovations (GENI) has supported a wide range of networking and computing systems research into future internet architectures, Software Defined Networking (SDN), wireless and mobile networks, network hardware and software approaches, network applications, network monitoring, network security, future clouds, distributed computing and edge clouds, and smart cities. GENI has been credited with key contributions including developing a federated approach for provisioning, accessing, and programming distributed cyberinfrastructure through standard abstractions, APIs, and security policies. 

Experimentation continues today, executed by a growing number of GENI users who are using it both as a research and an educational tool. Recent GENI experiments include work on evaluating future exascale systems, securing scientific workflows, defining and testing novel Software Define eXchange (SDX) architectures, network security research, and routing and transport protocol evaluations.

This proposal, Enabling NeTwork Research and the Evolution of a Next Generation Midscale Research Infrastructure (ENTeR) seeks to update, adapt, operate and maintain the existing GENI infrastructure for a two year time period in order to support ongoing at-scale network research experiments. At the same time, the project will engage in planning for next generation experimental research infrastructure. ENTeR will facilitate the transition from GENI to a new platform capable of supporting a much larger experimental research community. The ENTeR team's primary focus will be to ensure that the critical portions of the GENI infrastructure needed by the majority of researchers remain available and relevant. GENI will expand its role as an interconnect fabric between various elements of national experimental cyber infrastructure like NSF Future Clouds (i.e., Chameleon Cloud and CloudLab) and the Platforms for Advanced Wireless Resesearch (PAWR), linking them to campus networks and offering a rich set of new experimental capabilities. This project will provide opportunities for students to work on live distributed infrastructure, troubleshoot real problems, and develop software solutions that will be used by a large community of researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For more than a decade researchers have been using the Global Environment for Networking Innovations (GENI) to experiment with future internet architectures, applications, and services.  Educators across the globe have been using GENI to provide hands-on experience and training to students studying the latest topics in areas such as computer communications, networking, cybersecurity, and cloud computing.

 

To ensure the continued success of GENI and the large number of researchers and educators who use it, the ENTeR project (Enabling NeTwork Research and the Evolution of a Next Generation Midscale Research Infrastructure) focused on supporting and maintaining GENI's many unique capabilities while enhancing the services it offers as well as designing and planning for a future network infrastructure capable of supporting an even larger research community and range of experiments.

 

At the start of the project the team transitioned GENI from the GENI Project Office to the ENTeR team and made a number of key improvements in the areas of security, software updates and user management and support.

 

As an important first step toward better understanding and supporting the needs of users, the project developed and sent out a survey focused on collecting information from recent GENI users. The survey results indicated a high level of research productivity among users in terms of research papers published using GENI and also showed many faculty using GENI to teach classes with total enrollment in the thousands of students.  A summary of the survey results was shared with the community and also aided in shaping our efforts to develop future testbed infrastructure, services, and materials.

 

To help network operators and experimenters better understand the behaviors they were observing in the network, we developed an advanced monitoring and measurement service that makes it easy to deploy measurement capabilities across GENI and visualize the measurement data collected by the system.  The resulting measurement capabilities were later used to lay the groundwork for the measurement software used in the NSF FABRIC network infrastructure.

 

Another important part of the  transition to FABRIC involved the ENTeR team migrating users, experiments, tutorials, and assignments to the new FABRIC infrastructure.  In particular, the team ported many of the GENI tutorials and assignments to work on FABRIC and also created documentation describing the procedures for continued use of these materials on FABRIC.  In addition, the ENTeR team worked directly with instructors to help them create class accounts on FABRIC and convert their class projects from GENI to FABRIC.

 

Throughout the transition process, the ENTeR team was actively engaged not only in the planning and design of FABRIC, but was also involved in the efforts to promote federation among the NSF-funded infrastructure projects, including participation in MERIF workshops focusing on the design of midscale experimental infrastructures.

 

In summary, the ENTeR project continued to serve as a valuable testbed resource to the research and education community while at the same time planning for and eventually migrating the community to the new FABRIC infrastructure.  Many of the materials and services resulting from this project have been integrated into FABRIC and/or posted on FABRIC's websites and associated repositories.
